title: CVPR_2010_30_abs

sentences.text: We introduce a method to accelerate the evaluation of object detection cascades with the help of a divide-and-conquer procedure in the space of candidate regions .

Compared to the exhaustive procedure that thus far is the state-of-the-art for cascade evaluation , the proposed method requires fewer evaluations of the classifier functions , thereby speeding up the search .
Furthermore , we show how the recently developed efficient subwindow search -LRB- ESS -RRB- procedure -LSB- 11 -RSB- can be integrated into the last stage of our method .

This allows us to use our method to act not only as a faster procedure for cascade evaluation , but also as a tool to perform efficient branch-and-bound object detection with nonlinear quality functions , in particular kernel-ized support vector machines .
Experiments on the PASCAL VOC 2006 dataset show an acceleration of more than 50 % by our method compared to standard cascade evaluation .

summary: We introduce a method to accelerate the evaluation of object detection cascades with the help of a divide-and-conquer procedure in the space of candidate regions . Compared to the exhaustive procedure that thus far is the state-of-the-art for cascade evaluation , the proposed method requires fewer evaluations of the classifier functions , thereby speeding up the search . Furthermore , we show how the recently developed efficient subwindow search -LRB- ESS -RRB- procedure -LSB- 11 -RSB- can be integrated into the last stage of our method . This allows us to use our method to act not only as a faster procedure for cascade evaluation , but also as a tool to perform efficient branch-and-bound object detection with nonlinear quality functions , in particular kernel-ized support vector machines . Experiments on the PASCAL VOC 2006 dataset show an acceleration of more than 50 % by our method compared to standard cascade evaluation .

Predicate-introduce.label: introduce
Predicate-introduce.description: To introduce means to bring into existence or awareness something new, such as an idea, concept, process, or methodology. It implies a sense of novelty and often involves presenting or revealing the subject's characteristics, features, or benefits for the first time.

Predicate-accelerate.label: accelerate
Predicate-accelerate.description: To accelerate means to increase the speed or rate at which something occurs, often by improving efficiency or reducing complexity. In this sense, it connects the subject and object by indicating a transformation that enables faster processing, computation, or evaluation of the subject's activity.

Predicate-requires_fewer_evaluations_of.label: requires fewer evaluations of
Predicate-requires_fewer_evaluations_of.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a reduced need for assessments or judgments regarding the object. It suggests that the subject's introduction, definition, or characterization of the object can be accomplished with fewer evaluations or criteria.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: To employ or apply something (typically an idea, method, tool, etc.) for a specific purpose or context.

Predicate-act_as_a_faster_procedure_for.label: act as a faster procedure for
Predicate-act_as_a_faster_procedure_for.description: The predicate 'act as a faster procedure for' indicates that the subject (a method or process) serves to accelerate or streamline the execution of the specified task or activity described by the object. In general, this predicate highlights how the subject contributes to improving efficiency and speed in achieving the desired outcome.

Predicate-perform_efficient_branch-and-b.label: perform efficient branch-and-bound object detection with nonlinear quality functions
Predicate-perform_efficient_branch-and-b.description: This predicate describes a process that efficiently detects objects by leveraging the combination of branch-and-bound optimization and nonlinear quality functions. It connects the subject (e.g., method, algorithm) to the object (e.g., kernel-ized support vector machines), indicating how the subject performs the described detection task with the specified approach.

Predicate-accelerates_by_more_than_50.label: accelerates by more than 50%
Predicate-accelerates_by_more_than_50.description: The predicate 'accelerates by more than 50%' indicates that a method or process has increased its speed or rate of progress by at least 50% compared to some baseline, standard, or expected value. This connection highlights the subject's ability to improve performance and efficiency.

Predicate-compared_to_standard_cascade_e.label: compared to standard cascade evaluation
Predicate-compared_to_standard_cascade_e.description: This predicate indicates that a subject (typically an object detection method or algorithm) has its performance evaluated and compared to a standard cascade evaluation approach, providing insight into how well it performs relative to this established benchmark.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is related to or encompasses the object as a more general concept. It suggests a hierarchical relationship between the two, where the subject represents a higher-level category and the object falls within it.
